Column: 563

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
(Seventh Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [10th August, 1960],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly.".'-(The Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.31 p.m.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I first touch on two matters upon which the Member for Cairnhill laboured the day before yesterday?

    First, the deregistration of the four federations. There is a lot of smoke over this. Sir, as a result of the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Cairnhill being on the same side in wishing to

Column: 564

generate smoke. Obviously, something must have gone wrong. Otherwise how could a Government register a federation and a few days later deregister it along with the other federations? Suffice it to say, Sir, that this was not unconnected with the issue of an entry visa for a Communist Russian representative to come to Singapore. From time to time, the Singapore Government is queried by the Internal Security Council for not taking the advice of the Singapore Government's own Intelligence section. The Intelligence section had recommended against the issue of a visa for a Russian communist representative to come to Singapore for trade. However, the Minister for Finance, together with the Minister for Home Affairs, had over-ruled this objection and had allowed the visa. Meanwhile, the same Intelligence department of the Singapore Government had given advice that a certain general employees' union should not be allowed to register with a federation unless their rues were changed to comply with the new Trade Unions Ordinance and they had first divested themselves of those sections of their membership not qualified to be members of the union under the new trade union laws. This advice was endorsed by the Minister for Home Affairs but, unfortunately, it was overlooked by the Minister for Labour and Law, for he had allowed a federation which included this particular general employees' union to be registered on the' promise of this union that when the new laws came into effect they would comply with them. The question that had been raised in the Internal Security Council was over the visa for a Russian representative on the principle that the Singapore Government had on an important matter ignored advice from the Singapore Government's own Intelligence department. The view of the Singapore Government was that it had the right to over-rule advice from its Intelligence section where it deemed it was in the public interest, and where it considered no grave security risk was involved. But in the case of the advice on the registration of the federation, this advice from the Singapore Government's

Column: 565

own Intelligence department was endorsed by the Minister for Home Affairs, and a non-observance of this advice was difficult to defend on principle. Therefore, for reasons of security arising out of an issue of principle in the Internal Security Council, the Singapore Government decided to rectify the mistake made in the case of the registration of the federation. It was decided to deregister all the federations and allow them to re-register after the new trade union laws had come into force. The new trade union laws would make it incumbent on general unions to comply first with the 19 categories laid down in the Schedule before they can register as federations.

    I beg your pardon, Mr Speaker, Sir, I have just received a note to remind me that we are now multi-lingual.

    Sir, about the visa for the Russian representative, the Member for Cairnhill made great play of what could or could not be discussed in the Internal Security Council. I am glad that he stood up for the right of the Singapore Government to decide what was right or wrong in matters of internal self-government. Questions of trade and immigration, Sir, are matters within the competence of the Singapore Government, but because, in exercising its competency in a particular instance, the Singapore Government had over-ruled the views of its own Intelligence branch, the Internal Security Council had made an issue of this. However, the Member for Cairnhill raised another by-issue on this, for he wanted to make capital out of a denial by the Minister for Culture. I did not hear him say this, Sir, the day before yesterday, but it was reported in the Straits Times that he had said these words: "Then Mr Lee issued another statement verifying the Tunku's claim was materially correct." [Interruption] Sir, I am glad that the Member for Cairnhill has denied making that statement, because he was so reported to have said it. What happened was this. The Minister for Finance, immediately after the issue was raised by the Federation Government in the Press and after the Minister for Culture had issued his statement, wrote to his counterpart in Kuala Lumpur setting out the facts. If I may just refer to the relevant parts of that letter which

Column: 566

was subsequently released to the Press and whose contents were made known in Kuala Lumpur. Sir, I do not wish to waste the time of the House by reading the full letter. All I wish to point out is that the view of the Singapore Government was that the Russian delegation to the E.C.A.F.E. Conference on small-scale industries did not constitute a Russian trade delegation, and that one representative coming here did not constitute a trade delegation, particularly as he had come in here with the specific purpose of attending an E.C.A.F.E. Conference on small-scale industries. I can only add that the Minister for Culture had no intention at any time to state other than what he personally knew to be the truth and that, in fact, in his and in the Government's view of the matter, there was no Russian trade delegation as such.

    Sir, I am more concerned, however, with the mendacious line that has been taken by the Member for Cairnhill when he suggested that the P.A.P. was Communist-infiltrated and Communist-dominated. He suggested, Sir, by insinuation that we were keeping in our membership a number of Communist sympathisers and activists. Sir, as someone who has been intimately connected with the organs of the State, the hon. Member must know what stupidity it is to make so dangerous an allegation of a Government in power. The fact that we did not, and do not still, take a hysterical anti-Communist line is quite a different matter from harbouring Communists and others who are insincere in their loyalty to the aims and objectives of the P.A.P. Otherwise, how on earth can we govern with effectiveness and firmness? It is a pity, Sir, to hear this dangerous drivel emanating from people whose former positions should at least have given them a sense of responsibility, or should have imparted in them some wisdom.

    Sir, the Member for Cairnhill denied that Communist forces had gone underground before the last elections. I do not know what he was inferring by that. If what he stated is true, then what he is, in fact, saying is that his two purges - one in 1956 and one in 1957 - were completely ineffective. That, Sir, to my

Column: 567

mind is a foolish statement. The fact that fringe elements were left out of the purge - and they were left out for a definite purpose - because it was wise policy not to treat fringe elements as Communists, and the fact that the bulk of the Chinese-speaking was so convinced that the last Government was a corrupt force, anti Chinese language, education and culture that they set out actively to work to destroy the hon. Member in the last elections, do not make them Communists, Sir. Whatever the price the last Government paid for losing the propaganda battle and the battle for the minds of the Chinese in the two purges, they succeeded in disrupting the efficacy of the Communist open front organisers and the rest of them did go under cover - to his knowledge. Whether he was wise in taking on the fight on his own behalf when the challenge was, in fact, to be met ultimately by the British is another matter which I shall deal with later on in my speech. But I feel sad, Sir, that an ex-Chief Minister should make a half-hearted call for general elections. It is only a gesture to show that he is not a spent political force. For 4½ years, his Labour Fronters clung on to power in this Assembly upon the strength of nominated Members, and jobs for every one. Here is a Government determined to govern within the limits of its power, invested with the power and the right to govern, and the hon. Member calls for general elections! Sir, let me add that he may find his wish fulfilled earlier than he expects if the eventuality should arise in which the Left-wing adventurers find themselves not just taking on the Singapore Government but also "the referee", as the Member for Cairnhill has called the Internal Security Council.

    Sir, before I leave the other minor points in the speech of the Member for Cairnhill, may I correct some of the more obvious mistakes made in either the speech or the report of his speech in the Straits Times? May I mention incidentally, Sir, that to deny and refute every untruth, every half-truth and every half-lie made in this Chamber would be an extremely tedious and a time-wasting process? So far as we are concerned,

Column: 568

Sir, any allegation made in this Chamber, unless admitted, is denied and traversed generally.

    An hon. Member: Ha, ha, ha!

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the hon. Member has said that I had told him that he was fishing in troubled waters and that I had expressed to him great confidence in my then colleague the Minister for National Development. Sir, this was supposed to have taken place in March this year, to my recollection, when I warned him not to fish in troubled waters. But what I did tell him was not to fish in troubled waters, and I said no more, because by March this year the weaknesses in the former Minister for National Development had already become apparent. And I could go on ad infinitum, all these little misquotations, misreferences, that I had called people "little boys" and all the rest of it; things that I have not said are imputed to me. I would like it to be put on record that nothing is admitted unless it is specifically admitted, and that anything else which is not admitted is specifically traversed and denied. As a pleader, my learned friend should know that that is an economical way of dealing with mendacious opponents.

    Next, Mr Speaker, Sir, may I turn to what to me is a sad and painful thing, to have to denounce a man who has been a colleague for many years, a person who, through one phase of the struggle for freedom, we thought shared with us a common cause. We knew he had his weaknesses; we did not realise, however, how much power was to enlarge and accentuate his weaknesses to reach breaking point. The trouble with the Member for Hong Lim, Sir, is that he is more a plotter and a schemer than a thinker and a planner. It is all right shouting slogans, working out cunning little lines on the details after the broad policy has been settled by a team of thinkers. How is he going to fight colonialism in this phase of the battle? He no longer believes in the programme or the political analysis of the P.A.P. What is his alternative? How is he going to bring about merger? How is he going

Column: 569

to bring about independence for Singapore by itself? These are abiding issues of great political import. I hope from now onwards we will from time to time divert ourselves from our more mundane duties to pay attention to these long-term problems.

    However, let me first point out to him some of the rather obvious absurdities and contradictions of this propaganda line - the Lee Kuan Yew Government. Sir, everybody is a nice man, except me.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: You are nicer!

    The Prime Minister: As I said yesterday when explaining the definition of "people", it is always useful to start off with one opponent first. The rest are the "people". You fight that opponent and, after you have destroyed him, you go on with the process of elimination.

    Sir, you are a fine gentleman. I do not know the distinction between a fine and an unfine gentleman; obviously there must be.

    Well, the Minister for Culture is all right; he is a reasonable chap. So is Mr Byrne except when he loses his temper. The Minister for Home Affairs is a nice man, quiet and peace-loving. And Dr Toh, who unfortunately is away today attending to multifarious other duties and trying to clear up some mess left behind by a former colleague, he is also all right. But I forced the Assemblymen - 40 of them, Sir - to sign statements against him. I packed a gun and surrounded all of them with Sten guns, and my henchmen pulled them in. Sir, the whole Cabinet, the whole Central Executive Committee, consist of weak, vacillating puppets. Is this not a little bit too obvious? May I suggest that a little bit more balance, less accentuation of simple black and white, would make his line a little bit more effective? Does he realise that these are men not so completely devoid of self-respect as to be humoured in this amateurish manner? Are they stooges of the Secretary-General? If I am the evil man who manipulates the puppets, and I am strong-willed, ambitious and powerful how does this square up with the other line of the stooge of the English - me, a stooge of Blades. Meadows, and Thomson?

Column: 570



    Sir, the projection of a dictator with wild ambitions, determined and obviously successful in manipulating all the Central Executive, the Cabinet, the Party Secretariat, the officials in the Party - is this not a process of projection of one's own motives, one's own plotting, one's own thinking and methods, which failed so miserably? Sir, on the one hand I am a stooge, weak, feeble and docile, and I am, in fact, run by Blades. Thomson and Meadows - they run me, they run the Government, they run the P.A.P. On the other hand, I am a powerful character who manipulates my colleagues by terror and with bribes, guns and jobs, and perks. Sir, I do not pretend to be suffering from any psychiatric disorders at the moment, and I hope I never will. I think those of us who have been in this Chamber for the last five years will know that from time to time we get this malady in this Chamber. In fact, I was thinking the other day that it was absolutely vital that we should amend our Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance, because it is out of date. There should be a clause there to say that a doctor must certify an Assemblyman compos mentis before he makes a major speech in the Assembly. We have seen it enacted before in the past.

    Sir, I am no `Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde'. Does the Member for Hong Lim believe that Dr Toh, whom he denounced anonymously in the name of his Hong Lim Branch Committee, was guilty of what he called the Chairman's undemocratic conduct? Does he believe that Dr Toh is a stooge?

    Mr Speaker: Deputy Prime Minister.

    The Prime Minister: Deputy Prime Minister, Sir - a research scientist, with no personal political ambitions of greatness. Why should he be a stooge, Sir? I am not looking after the funds of the University to supply him with expenses and equipment for his laboratory tests; unless he is carrying out tests on some mysterious creatures which I am providing him with.

    An hon. Member: Beetle!

Column: 571



    The Prime Minister: And the Member for Crawford, the Member for Kampong Glam, and the Member for Telok Ayer. I am glad, Sir, that he did not say that the Member for Sembawang was a nice gentleman, because he has been going around telling all the Malay Assemblymen here what a nasty fellow be [the Member for Sembawang] was, and that he was a stooge of the Secretary-General. It is a good thing he did not have the audacity to say so, for I think he knows that the Member for Sembawang is a man likely to take him out and tear him to strips.

    However, let us get on to the facts, Sir. Allegations and counter-allegations - very wise and judicious, in the opinion of the Member for Farrer Park, because they leave him very much in the dark. Let us first get these three bogey-men out of the way: Mr George Thomson, former Director of Information, a powerful man in the old days and, to the Member for Hong Lim, an even more powerful individual now. What were his duties in the last Government, Sir? For the last few years before 1959, he gave the political line and the political content, and he was the propaganda machine for the Chief Minister. He did the political thinking for the Chief Minister's Ministerial colleagues, a thing which they did not do for themselves. And we denounced them because they did not have the ideological substance to do their own speeches. We denounced them for just mouthing the speeches of an expatriate officer. It is not to say we did not recognise Mr Thomson's ability and usefulness to us for a particular job. We had to re-educate our civil servants on the problems which confronted us and which he, as Director of Information, should have known something about, and because it is our business to make the civil servants more alive and alert to the dangers and difficulties of the revolution in Asia. Is the Member for Hong Lim prepared or intellectually equipped to do the lectures and to teach the civil servants? His only contribution to political thinking in all his years in the P.A.P. has been one article in this Souvenir number to

Column: 572

which he had pledged his loyalty and support. It is entitled "Since I became the First Mayor of Singapore". Is he going to educate the civil service with this? Fortunately, Sir, the P.A.P. is not altogether devoid of leaders who can undertake the intellectual task of making an ideological exposition of democratic socialism. Let us get this clear. Mr George Thomson is a functionary in the Political Study Centre. He arranges the lectures and the discussions. The political line, the policies, the programmes of this Political Study Centre were laid down and are still being laid down by a Committee under the chairmanship of the Minister for Culture, consisting, amongst others, of Mr James Puthucheary, Mr Devan Nair, Mr Jek Yuen Thong, Mr S. Woodhull, and Inche Rahim Ishak. Ministers, Parliamentary Secretaries and Political Secretaries, Sir, personally go there from time to time to conduct discussions and lectures. The only Minister who has not done so and has not been invited to do so was the ex-Minister, the Member for Hong Lim, because it would not have done the political leadership any good to put up a slogan-shouter in the Study Centre, or put him forward as a serious thinker. Sir, he should have attended these lectures given by Mr Devan Nair, Mr James Puthucheary and others. Then perhaps he might have acquired some ideological knowledge to coin some of the new slogans which he must now forge if he wants to survive politically.

    Next, Sir, is Mr Blades, this evil man. Whom does he manipulate? Does he manipulate the Minister for Home Affairs? Sir, on the one hand, I am being accused of complete control and manipulation of the Police Force. On the other hand, I am told I have been manipulated by Mr Blades. The Member for Hong Lim has to make up his mind. A propaganda line has to be clear, simple, lucid, and not contradictory. Either I am strong and I manipulate both the Minister for Home Affairs and the Commissioner of Police; or the Commissioner of Police is strong and manipulates both me and the Minister for Home Affairs. The Member for Hong Lim thinks that by

Column: 573

glossing over all this, he has prevented injury to the personality of the Minister for Home Affairs, who is an important Party functionary - the Organising Secretary in charge of the Party apparatus. Does he not know that, by saying all this, what he is, in fact, saying is either the Minister for Home Affairs is my stooge or Mr Blades is his stooge, or Mr Blades is a stooge of both? And he thinks that that is a clever line! Sir, has he forgotten how seriously we thought over this problem of the Police Force, and how we strongly pressed for the promotion of the most senior local officer as Deputy Commissioner of Police, and are pressing for arrangements whereby those local officers can prepare themselves for their new and vigorous responsibilities? Sir, no one knows better than these officers themselves how inadequately the colonial government of the past had equipped them as officers to take over the top jobs of the civil service in the Police Force. And they themselves had told the Malayanisation Commission that for several years to come, they would not be ready to take over the top jobs in the Police Force.

    Sir, the Member for Hong Lim, now that he is deprived of power, is only interested in bringing the house down. We are not going to allow that to happen. We are here to see that the State and the machinery of the State functions, and no amount of challenge, either insidious or otherwise, by Left-wing adventurers or whoever else is going to put us into a false position.

    Sir, in extremis, one could get a situation like the Congo Army, where a Serjeant major suddenly finds himself as general in charge of an army of all corporals and no privates, because all the privates have been promoted to corporals. I do not believe the situation in Singapore is anywhere remotely near that, but it is our business to ensure that the efficiency of the organs of the State is maintained.

    Sir, Mr Meadows - this man on Intelligence duties. The Member for Hong Lim wanted to keep Mr Meadows in his Ministry to help him. When he found that Mr Meadows was unwilling to be his personal minion, he

Column: 574

sent him out to the Southern Islands. When Mr Meadows came back from the Southern Islands, he found that the walls of his office, which had been put up on the orders of the ex-Minister, had been knocked down, and the air-conditioner removed. And this Intelligence duties man reacted in a manner unbecoming of an Intelligence agent. He did a human thing. He wanted to resign, to give up his job of spying. Then, Sir, the ex-Minister again wavered. He swung to the other side of the pendulum, because Mr Meadows was doing a good job of his Southern Islands task. But you cannot humiliate a man one day, pat him on the back the next, and tell him to forget that you kicked him in the teeth the day before. I did not plan to have Mr Meadows in my Ministry. He was to have been transferred to the Ministry of Home Affairs or the Ministry of Finance. But the Member for Hong Lim started his smear campaign, and so I asked for Mr Meadows to be transferred to my Ministry. It is one of my duties to put my foot down on what I know to be wrong and vicious. I allotted Mr Meadows a task which he should have performed for the Minister for National Development, namely, that of distributing the departments of the City Council and integrating them with the Government Ministries - a job he was never permitted to perform when he was in the Ministry of National Development.

    Sir, all these three bogey men are supposed to be occupying more powerful positions than before. The truth of these allegations, if left unrefuted, however wild and scandalous they may be, might find some takers. Therefore, it is my business, and I hope the House will bear with me if I go into some detail, to go through all these wild allegations on Malayanisation and expatriate officers making stooges of the Ministers of this Government.

    First of all, Sir, Mr Owen - the famous Mr Owen. Some people have greatness thrust upon them. Mr Owen got fame and glory overnight. He was sacked from the City Council. Three expatriates who retired were asked to return by me. The Member for Hong

Column: 575

Lim says I am a stooge man, Sir; a weak, vacillating character, and could not do without my expatriate masters.

    He said that Mr Estrop, a local electrical engineer, was going to be promoted for a big job in the electricity power station at Pasir Panjang, but he was thwarted by wicked, evil me. Let us confront the Member for Hong Lim with these facts.

    First, Malayanisation of the City Council. Sir, I do not want to run through these names. It is very tedious. There are a lot of details. Those of us who have' leisure time might browse through them. They might find considerable interest in them. So I propose to table these lists for the delectation of both the hon. Members of this Assembly and such members of the Press as may be interested in checking the veracity of my statement. The City Council Malayanisation policy was introduced into the City Council and passed by the Member for Hong Lim, as the then Mayor, on the 30th June, 1958. And there is a verbatim report of the ordinary general meeting held on that day which has been placed in the records.

    Sir, the ex-Mayor proposed that of the 71 expatriate officers then in the City Council, only 8 were to be malayanised immediately, leaving 63 to be malayanised as follows:

    5 guaranteed employment until retirement;

    16 until 1st June, 1959, or retirement at 55, or optional retirement at 50;

    11 until 1st January, 1964, or retirement at 55, or optional retirement at 50;

    11 until 1st January, 1962,

a total of 63 from all departments - technicians, technocrats in the Electricity, Architects, Water, Analysts, Chemical, Gas and other Departments.

    Now let us turn to Mr Estrop - the local man whom I was alleged to have thwarted. He is a qualified electrical engineer, Sir. He was posted by a man called Lui Boon Poh. I think it was mentioned that he had a peculiar habit

Column: 576

of waking up at 5 o'clock in the morning - that is about his only virtue, I think. He was in charge at one time of cleansing. Then he became Deputy Administrator. He posted Mr Estrop to be No. 2 in charge of the Pasir Panjang Power Station without Mr Estrop having the necessary legal qualifications for the job - a requirement laid down by the Machinery Ordinance and the Rules thereunder. I know that in the process of revolution one could ignore the niceties of the law. But when it came to my notice that a man who did not have the necessary mechanical qualifications was put in charge of a power station, it left me aghast. It says here in this Factories (Persons-in-Charge) Regulations, 1960. Regulation 3.

    `No person shall be in charge of any boiler, steam engine or internal combustion engine, except as provided in these regulations.'

And it says here:

    `(7) Where the heating surface of a steam boiler or the aggregate heating surface of steam boilers connected to a common range exceeds five thousand square feet a first grade steam engineer shall... be in charge... to ensure that there shall not be more than two steam boilers to each attendant.'

Mr Estrop was not a first grade steam engineer. He was put back to what he was qualified to do - a distribution engineer. I am sorry, Sir, Mr Estrop is a serving officer. There is nothing against him. But I would like to mention that I have had to make reference to him purely because he was brought up as an issue. But he had no mechanical engineering experience or steam experience. The man who did this hazardous and, in my view, completely stupid piece of posting was Lui Boon Poh, then Deputy Administrator in charge of the three mechanical trading departments of Gas, Water and Electricity.

    Mr Lui Boon Poh was educated at Batu Pahat where he attained Standard VIII. He had previously been a salesman.

    Mr Ong Eng Guan: On a point of clarification, Mr Speaker.

    The Prime Minister resumed his seat.

Column: 577



    Mr Ong Eng Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, before we posted Mr Estrop to the Pasir Panjang Power Station, we had a meeting with four or five qualified local engineers in the Electricity Department. The meeting was held in the Ministry of National Development. It continued for 2 or 3 days. It was agreed among us that Mr Estrop was a fit and proper person to be deputy to the Superintendent of the Pasir Panjang Power Station. After we had made the decision, I instructed the Administrator to carry it out.

    The Prime Minister: I am obliged for all these further details, and that there were some minds brought to bear on this problem. But there is just one simple point. Wisdom accumulated over years of manipulating this dangerous equipment has laid down that there should be a man with a certain kind of training to look after this kind of machinery, and our law enacted by this Legislature, through subsidiary legislation, has so specified. Mr Estrop was unqualified. He did not have that particular qualification, and the posting was illegal. It was contrary to the law. That is all.

    Let us go back to Mr Lui Boon Poh - obviously he was a stooge man, it did not matter - who was told to do it. He was not really responsible for this. He was educated -

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the Prime Minister is satisfied that this man, Lui Boon Poh, is a stooge of a group of people, as he has mentioned, then is it fair now to go into details about the character and the career of this man? I know the Prime Minister is protected by freedom of speech in this Assembly, but perhaps he would think twice before he carries on this line.

    The Prime Minister: I am sorry you should anticipate evil motive when there is none, Sir. The whole thing is -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I hope the Prime Minister does not say that the Chair has imputed evil motive. I am just indicating -

Column: 578



    The Prime Minister: Anticipating.

    Mr Speaker: I am just indicating that the Member for Hong Lim has pointed out to this House that this particular decision was not a decision of this man Lui Boon Poh.     We have to struggle not only for socialism, but for the nationalist basis of socialism. Thus, our most pressing initial problem today is that of nation-building in a multiracial society.'

Not slogan-shouting, back to 1954.

    `The real struggle for socialism in Malaya can only begin when our people, Malays, Chinese and Indians are able to transcend the communal cultural and linguistic barriers and loyalties which at present divide them, and embrace a common Malayan loyalty and cultivate a common national consciousness.'

Sir, I propose to table this* also in this House, and I only wish to read two short extracts. It is cogent, coherent and completely in accord with the aims, objectives and analysis of the P.A.P.

    `"Once the problem of linguistic and cultural unity is on the way to being resolved, fears and suspicions will fade away."'

The five gentlemen read the Anniversary Souvenir and quoted it with their approval. Upon this Anniversary Souvenir, the working basis for any political co-operation between Left-wingers must rest. And they stated this, quoting from our P.A.P. document.

    `"Once the problem of linguistic and cultural unity is on the way to being resolved, fears and suspicions will fade away. We must face the facts. So long as the fight was against British colonialism, the differences between the peoples of Malaya were muted and dulled in the desire to achieve the common goal of freedom by common effort. Now that this freedom has been won in the Federation all the differences come back into their own. They can and must be resolved. And we in Singapore can set the way to the solution of these important differences in language and culture. That is what we can and must do in this next phase of our struggle for freedom, the struggle for merger."'

And they went on to say in their own words, Sir:

And I want to add here, `Left-wing adventurers, please watch out.' And it ends up:

And the most important task of socialists in this new phase is to achieve complete identification with the ideal of a united Malayan nation, and to struggle by peaceful, democratic and constitutional means for the enduring objective of an united, independent, democratic, non-communist and socialist Malaya.'

Sir, this was a declaration of political faith and principles, in complete accord with the policies and programmes of the P.A.P. which they made when they were released. On this political stand we appointed four of them as Political Secretaries, Needless to say, Sir, if any deviation is made from this stand, then the working basis is gone.     One of them, Mr Devan Nair, has resigned his position some time in March this year. My colleagues and I are sure

that he is completely sincere to the aims and objectives of the P.A.P. and has not deviated from his stand. He had personal reasons for his decision.

    Post-mortems are valuable in so far as we can draw lessons from them Does the former Chief Minister now know how he was out-manoeuvred and out-propagandaed by the. C.P. in October 1956? He held himself out as the defender of the democratic system in Singapore. In the defence of democracy, he had to purge the Chinese High School and the Chung Cheng High School. The fatal thing was the interpretation in the minds of the Chinese that he was purging not a few Communist students in the high schools but was purging Chinese culture, education and civilisation, and, of course, the accompanying working up of popular sentiment led by C.P. activists broke up in riots. When rioting took place, it was not the former Chief Minister who restored law and order. It was the supreme authority and the ultimate source of power, namely, the British army, which quashed the riots and re-established order. In the minds of the people during those few days of rioting, the Chief Minister, far from being the defender of democracy, appeared a tool of the British, whose General took over command of the Operations Room, and whose troops were out on every bridge and every important, intersection in town. Hence he lost out in the hearts and minds of the Chinese population. He lost out in the propaganda battle. He went in hoping to pick the leaders. The leaders wrapped themselves up in Chinese culture, language and education, and he lost them.

    Sir, the Member for Farrer Park is dead right. We are the source of power now - the open authority - and therefore the challenge, if made, would apparently at first be made against us. But ultimately it is a challenge against the

supreme authority here - the British army. The question which the Left-wing adventurers have to face, if such a similar situation were to arise, is this: how to find a reason for saying that the present Government are stooges? They found a multitude of reasons to say why the last Government were stooges, and some of them unfortunately were true. The former Minister for Education let his side down, and all kinds of other foolish things were done. These things stuck. But this is a different proposition for them to deal with. Nobody - even the Member for Hong Lim - even in a mo ment of madness, can accuse this Government of being corrupt. That is basic and fundamental, because once that forte is gone, then you drift with the winds. Sir, I do not want to be immodest. But as a statement of fact, the $3,050 that I get for my duties - I think the Member for Farrer Park will bear me out - is what I could earn, as any reasonably proficient lawyer could earn, in a long working week-end in the Federation or in Borneo, and not altogether an unpleasant working weekend either. Therefore, they must find a motive for our being stooges. I will tell them why they will fail if they cannot find this motive. Because if you embark on a smear, you can create what the C.I.D. call a "miasma of dubiety", such as befogged the Member for Farrer Park. He was not quite sure which side was telling the truth, he said. But if at the end of it all you have not got one salient and cogent fact upon which you can rest and say that, that is the truth, then the whole smear floats down-stream and is washed up. I say to them that at the end of it, in this battle which, if they are foolhardy enough to start before they are prepared for it, I am pretty sure they will find what we shall prove to the people, that we are stooges of our own convictions, our belief that the salvation of our people and Malaya depends upon the creation of a united people, based on one common language

and one common loyalty, despite its divergent races, and on the creation of a socialist society. I am not afraid to stand here or anywhere else to say that this is what my colleagues and I stand for.

    Sir, the Member for Cairnhill alleged yesterday that the P.A.P. is playing a double game, one game with the British and one game with the Communists. The Member for Tanglin said that the PAP, intends to do something dishonourable, for we have said that if there is a collision between these two opposing forces, then the P.A.P. would duck. The Member for Cairnhill, in one of his brighter moments of punning and clowning, said that when these two forces clash, the P.A.P. might well turn into a dead duck. Speaking from personal experience, I give him full marks for confirming that that was what happened when the collision took place and he was in between. Sir, he never saw the inter-play of the different contending forces fighting for supremacy, and he died politically, not in May 1959, when the election took place, but in October 1956, when the stooge image was built up in the minds of the people. He saw himself on one side of the ring - this was his exposition - fighting for democracy, and on the other side, the Communists fighting for totalitarianism and Communism. And he still believes that that is the correct analysis, and that we, now that we are the Government, do our duty in that corner of the ring which is fighting for democracy. Sir, he does not understand that there are three main contending forces in a three-cornered fight. There are three boxers in the ring. We are neither fighting the Communists alone nor the British alone. That is the point. The Member for Tanglin will remember that I quoted him something from 1957, that there was a three-cornered fight, and how one corner got the two other corners to weaken and then he triumphed. But not to be in between, or he would have been squashed.

    I put this question to the Member for Cairnhill, and if he looks back over the years, he will confirm that this is true. He will remember that the Tunku, when he fought the Communists, took an anti-Communist line only after he was sure that he was given Merdeka. Once Merdeka was obtained and the British forces were out of the: political ring, then it became a straight fight between the Tunku, on behalf of those who want a democratic system, and the M.C.P., on behalf of the Communists. The point is that this is not the position in Singapore. We are not an independent State and are not likely to be one until we get merger. And there are still three forces contending in the political arena.

    I was intrigued by the Member for Cairnhill's reference to the role of the Internal Security Council. After quoting the relevant provisions of the Report of the Constitution Commission, paragraph 32, he said:

    `The Internal Security Council is there to be a referee in a game between the Communists and the Singapore Government, and that they (the referee) would only exert their authority in two situations. First, if either the Government turns out to be weak and vacillating, or, second, if it refuses to discharge its responsibilities and protect the interest of the people and is a bad Government.'

Sir, I do not know who thought out this political profundity for him. But he is propounding, wittingly or unwittingly, a false piece of political analysis. If he wants to compare the I.S.C. to a referee, may I say that it is more the kind of referee one finds in all-in wrestling matches where, far from being just a referee between two contestants, very often the referee goes and wallops one contender to the floor and beats him up? Let us never forget this. Ultimate power rests not on section 65 or 66 of the Singapore (Constitution) Order in Council,

Column: 600

but in the reality of the forces whose will can prevail. Any challenge made to ultimate authority will be made, in fact, not to the Singapore Government, whose force is not the supreme one in Singapore, but to the British Government, whose dictum is final. Therefore, to go and stand in front of the British armed forces when a collision is going to take place between them and the forces of violent revolution on the other side is, in my submission, political foolhardiness. But let me add that that is not to say that the Singapore Government intends to abdicate and abjure authority under the Constitution. Within the limits of our jurisdiction, we accept our responsibility; and within the constitutional framework where a challenge is made to our authority, it is the business and the intention of the Government to assert its authority. But it is idle to believe that there may not again be a challenge by unconstitutional and violent methods to overawe and overthrow authority. The only answer to these methods of violent revolution is force. In the three-cornered fight which still continues in Singapore, it is the business of a non-Communist socialist Government to make use of the time between now and ultimate merger and independence in consolidating the democratic system, in consolidating the strength of the democratic forces, and to see that we are not used as somebody else's pawns.
